game_mode_info: Magos Lite lets you create two different types of game. In the first, the playerâ€™s character flies in the air. In the second, the player can make the character jump off the ground. In both types of game you can set the game mode, which is what the player needs to do to complete the game. In time mode, you set the duration of the game; the player will need to last that whole period to win. In distance mode, you set how far the player will need to travel to win. In survival mode, the game gets harder as it goes along because hazards appear more frequently. And you can set how much harder the game will get as it progresses.
player_info: Select an icon for the player to control in the game
background_info: Use these controls to create a background for your game. Behind the action there is a set of moving scenery panels that overlap to form the scene. If you want to, you can include up to three of these. During the game they will move from right to left at different speeds and this will make it look like your character is moving forwards.
separate multiple right answers with com: separate multiple right answers with comma
separate multiple wrong answers with com: separate multiple wrong answers with comma
memory_match_info: Memory is a maths game. The player is given a starting addition and has to catch the answer when it appears in the game. Catching that target generates the next target, which is the number just caught plus the second number in the initial addition. In this way a sequence of maths targets progressively appears for the player to catch. Insert here the first and second number that together form the starting addition.
match_info: The aim in this matching game is to pair two words that go together in some way. At the start of the game, the starting word is shown at the top of the screen. When the game commences, different words appear and move towards the player, together with other game objects to collect or avoid. The player has to identify the word that matches the starting word and catch it as it passes on the screen. This will win the player points but bumping into a wrong word will lose the player points. You can include more than one matching task in your game. When the player completes the first match, the next one immediately appears.
Either a task or an answer is missing!: Either a task or an answer is missing!

collectibles_info: Collectibles are moving elements that the player tries to collect in order to win game points. To collect them, the player has to bump into them as they approach. Use these controls to add collectibles to your game and to fix the frequency of their appearance.
Lose life if player collides with hazard: Does collision with a hazard make the player lose a life?
hazards_info: Hazards are moving elements that the player needs to avoid. If an approaching hazard hits the player, game points are lost. Use these controls to add hazards to your game and to fix the frequency of their appearance.  You can also decide whether the player will lose a life when hitting a hazard makes (see Powerups).
speed_info: Here you can define the speed of collectibles and hazards.
points_info: Use these controls to fix the points earned from collectibles and points lost from hazards.
powerups_info: Use these controls to fix  what powerups the player can collect. Extra lives will appear in 20-30 second intervals if activated.
stars_info: Use these controls to fix  how many points the player needs to earn star rewards. In time and distance mode the player has to clear the level (e.g. travel required distance) to earn stars.
instructions_info: Write the instructions for your game here. Try to make them as clear as possibile. Be sure to describe the main aim of the game.
